newsitem.title: UK: UK NATGAS SOFTER, DEPRESSED BY FUTURES SELLOFF.
newsitem.headline: UK NATGAS SOFTER, DEPRESSED BY FUTURES SELLOFF.

text.p: UK natural gas prices eased lower on Tuesday after heavy selling on the IPE September contract had a knock-on effect into the winter.
A major shipper dominated selling on the IPE, pushing the September contract down by 0.210 pence a therm to the psychologically important 9.00 pence level.
On the spot market, first quarter 1998 saw the most activity, with several deals done below 17 pence, at a low of 16.90 pence.
"There's a general bearish mood. September traded down which brought down levels in October and the rest of the winter," said one trader.
"There was a feeling that above 17 pence Q1 was overvalued relative to the rest of the curve" another added.
Prompt gas was heavily traded with one power generator buying more than half a dozen times on within day and day ahead gas. Prices slipped, with a day ahead deal at the NBP done at 9.0 pence.
October slipped about 0.10 pence a therm to trade at a low of 10.825 pence, and Q4 also slipped back to a low of 13.20 pence.
"People are realising that there really isn't a real amount of genuine bid interest out there," said one trader.
Next summer was thinly traded, with two deals for the second and third quarters at 10.90 pence and 10.85 pence.
